author: John Edens
title: New South Island ski area 'largely untouched since human habitation'
text:
New South Island ski area 'largely untouched since human habitation' JOHN EDENS Last updated 09:55, September 9 2015 Supplied 
A skier in action at the new ski area, Soho Basin, which has more than 260ha of terrain. 
The South Island site of an 'undiscovered' ski area has hardly changed since New Zealand was colonised, consent documents say. 
Soho Basin , nestled beside Cardrona Alpine Resort between Wanaka and Queenstown, is part of Glencoe Station alpine tussockland in the Southern Alps. 
The ski area is run by operations manager Mark Dewsbery and experienced ski area manager Hamish McCrostie, who ran The Remarkables and Coronet Peak for years. 
Soho Basin ski area is nestled beside Cardrona Alpine Resort between Queenstown and Wanaka. 
The company is owned by developer and Glencoe director John Darby. 
Billed as "undiscovered ," Soho is promoting the ski area as an exclusive chance to experience terrain as if it was the pioneering days of skiing in New Zealand back in the 1930s. 
Soho has been granted consent for a 1.2-kilometre chairlift and other infrastructure but McCrostie has stressed any development is a long way off as the business concentrates on introducing people to the terrain. Supplied 
Soho Basin ski area, near Cardrona, opened without fanfare earlier this winter. 
According to consent documents, a base station would be located on a "gently sloping natural platform" in the well of the basin and the top station on the edge of a small alpine basin beside Cardrona ski field. 
The consent material raises the possibility of connecting tracks to the commercial Cardrona ski area, whose previous owners applied to build a chairlift in the basin but the application did not progress in 1997. 
Soho's operators plan to focus on cat skiing and wide open off-piste terrain for the time being. 
"The site is characteristic of high altitude alpine tussockland of the Wakatipu region. Ad Feedback 
"The predominant aspect is south-west and southerly, resulting in cooler climatic conditions and longer snow cover. 
"At this altitude there has been minimal change during human colonisation, less so than lower areas where beech forest has been historically replaced by tussockland and pasture. 
"The introduction of grazing animals to the alpine landscape has had some degree of change with adaptation and modification of plant species. 
"The character of this landscape is typified by the emptiness of mountain peaks with wide vistas and long views. 
"Human intervention is uncommon, apart from the odd high country farm track," a Darby Partners landscape assessment says. 
Despite being billed as "undiscovered," the area is not exactly unexplored virgin territory. 
The basin has been used by back country skiers, heli-ski operators and film units for years but Soho are marketing an exclusive experience appealing to a sense of alpine adventure. 
The ski area is part of Glencoe Station, a vast high country tract, on land to the west of Cardrona ski field and part of a designated council ski area sub-zone. 
Soho's facilities - for now - include half-day and full day options for up to 24 people, snow cat groomers with heated cabs used for transport around the mountain and charters. 
Lunch, from Darby's Amisfield winery, can be provided for guests. 
The off-piste basin offers 500 metres of vertical drop, compared to 462 metres at Coronet Peak, 357m at The Remarkables, 600m at Cardrona and 700m at Treble Cone. 
Roundhill near Tekapo has the most vertical metres in New Zealand, 783m, closely followed by Turoa at Mt Ruapehu with 722m. - Stuff
